author: By Raja Abdulrahim and Ameera Harouda
title: With Temperatures Soaring, Gazans Swelter in Makeshift Tents
description: The tents that failed to keep out the cold when many Gazans first fled their homes have now become suffocating as highs surpass 100 degrees Fahrenheit.
content: When Maryam Arafat, her husband and their three young children fled their home in Gaza City under Israeli bombardment, it was the dead of winter. Forced to shelter in a ramshackle tent in Deir al Balah, the family shivered during the bitterly cold nights, as there was no fuel to heat up and not enough clothes to stay warm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Jacobs
title: F.D.A. Approves Antibiotic for Increasingly Hard-to-Treat Urinary Tract Infections
description: Pivmecillinam, which has been used in Europe for decades, will become available next year to women 18 and older.
content: The Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday approved the sale of an antibiotic for the treatment of urinary tract infections in women, giving U.S. health providers a powerful new tool to combat a common infection that is increasingly unresponsive to the existing suite of antimicrobial drugs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniela J. Lamas
title: Skepticism Is Healthy, but in Medicine, It Can Be Dangerous
description: Skepticism and distrust of health practitioners is on the rise. How are doctors supposed to restore patient trust?
content: I arrived at the hospital one recent morning to find a team of doctors gathered just outside a patient room. The patient was struggling — his breaths too fast and too shallow. For days we had been trying to walk the line between treating the pain caused by his rapidly growing cancer and prolonging his life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Horses Run Loose Through Central London in Surreal Spectacle
description: A number of runaway army horses galloped through London on Wednesday morning, causing alarm and injuring pedestrians. All of the animals were eventually recovered.
content: Several runaway military horses galloped through the streets of London on Wednesday morning, alarming pedestrians, sideswiping cars and buses, and turning an ordinary rush hour into a frightening, almost surreal spectacle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Review: Noche Flamenca, Raising the Dead With Goya
description: In “Searching for Goya,” at the Joyce Theater, the troupe uses the painter’s images as frames for flamenco dances.
content: As models for choreography, even the greatest painters are of limited use. Dance, for all of its concern with stage compositions, is an art of motion; painting, even when it implies action, is static. But painters can provide choreographers with an angle of vision, a way of looking at the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: We’re Adding New Songs to Our California Soundtrack
description: Our playlist reflects the breadth and diversity of the Golden State.
content: As a midweek pick-me-up, today I’m sharing some music for your listening pleasure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger
title: Elon Musk Clashes With Australian Court Over Violent Videos on X
description: Mr. Musk’s defiance over removing content is testing the boundaries of international legal systems.
content: An Australian court on Wednesday extended an injunction ordering the social media platform X to remove videos depicting the recent stabbing of a bishop, setting the country’s judicial system up for a clash with the company’s owner, Elon Musk, who has denounced the court’s order as censorship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Justices Seemed Split on Emergency Abortion Access
description: Also, U.S. weapons are headed to Ukraine. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
content: Supreme Court justices appeared sharply divided today over whether federal law should allow doctors to perform emergency abortions in states that have adopted near-total bans on the procedure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Reyburn
title: Long-Lost Klimt Painting Sells for $37 Million at Auction
description: The portrait was left unfinished in the painter’s studio when he died, and questions persist over the identity of the subject and what happened to the painting during Nazi rule in Austria.
content: “Portrait of Fräulein Lieser,” an enigmatic, long-lost 1917 painting by Gustav Klimt, sold Wednesday for 35 million euros with fees, or about $37 million, at the auction house im Kinsky in Vienna.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof, Sarah Wildman and Vishakha Darbha
title: Biden’s Deep Miscalculation on Israel and Gaza
description: Nicholas Kristof asks: Where has our moral president gone?
content: The war in Gaza has become President Biden’s war, the Times Opinion columnist Nicholas Kristof argues in a recent column criticizing what he describes as a moral failing on Biden’s part. In the following conversation, the Opinion editor Sarah Wildman asks Nick to elaborate on where he thinks Biden went wrong and what he hopes the president will do to try to end the conflict in the Middle East
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Elder
title: Why Indoor Soccer is the Beautiful Game at Its Best
description: In its flamboyance and entertainment factor, it embodies the spirit of street soccer, the real roots of the game.
content: Today, soccer enjoys a presence in America that the sport has never had before: Lionel Messi now plays here, and the 2026 World Cup will take place in 11 U.S. cities. “Ted Lasso” and “Welcome to Wrexham” have made soccer popular television. Yet for all that, it sometimes feels as if there’s no “there” there. The two most watched leagues — the Premier League and Liga MX — are based in England and Mexico. Thousands of people turn up for their local Major League Soccer, National Women’s Soccer League or minor-league teams, but they perform sanitized impersonations of European and Latin-American soccer culture, where teams tend to be rooted in their cities’ history. The sport’s prized stars, teams and tournaments have been purchased, backed and exploited by autocratic rulers, private equity firms and oligarchs. It can sometimes feel as if the romance of the game is slipping away, replaced by an increasingly plastic product.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Man Who Struck Officer With Pole on Jan. 6 Sentenced to 6 Years in Prison
description: The man, David Joseph Gietzen, had failed to show up in court and became a fugitive after a jury found him guilty of committing five felonies during the January 2021 attack on the Capitol.
content: A North Carolina man who was declared a fugitive after being found guilty last year of assaulting police officers during the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol was sentenced on Tuesday to six years in prison, a spokeswoman for the Justice Department said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: The International Date Line Is ‘Pretty Arbitrary.’ Here’s Why.
description: That squiggly line through the Pacific where days begin and end has no legal authority and technically doesn’t exist.
content: Taylor Swift flies to Las Vegas from Japan and gains several hours. Hong Kong’s stock market closes as London’s opens. A clock on a remote Pacific island strikes midnight 24 hours early on a politician’s order.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu
title: New Nutrition Guidelines Put Less Sugar and Salt on the Menu for School Meals
description: The Agriculture Department finalized a new rule to bring the meals more in line with federal dietary standards.
content: School meals will soon contain less salt and sugar, but can still include chocolate milk, under new nutrition guidelines released by the Biden administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Kenji López-Alt
title: What’s the Best Way to Salt Scrambled Eggs?
description: Paying close attention to timing can help you avoid watery eggs. Kenji López-Alt explains why.
content: In this column, Ask Kenji, the cookbook author Kenji López-Alt answers your questions. This week, he discusses the surprising science of salting scrambles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Hess
title: How a Virtual Assistant Taught Me to Appreciate Busywork
description: A new category of apps promises to relieve parents of drudgery, with an assist from A.I. But a family’s grunt work is more human, and valuable, than it seems.
content: I recently downloaded a virtual assistant that promised to ease the burdens of modern parenthood. The app is called Yohana, and it offered to handle a pile of tasks on my behalf. It suggested enlisting a professional to wash my windows, scheduling a lesson with a “private sports coach” or planning a “stylish and sustainable” Earth Day party featuring décor, recipes, activities and party favors, none of which interested me. Finally it volunteered to produce a “chef-curated menu” for Passover.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hope Reese
title: 7 Books on Navigating Grief
description: Psychologists, counselors and other experts share the titles they recommend most.
content: Joanna Luttrell is well acquainted with grief. The bereavement coordinator supports families that are navigating a child’s terminal illness at St. Jude’s Children’s Hospital in Memphis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review No. 1,040
description: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Boeing Loses $355 Million in Latest Quarter
description: The manufacturer has had to slow production of its popular 737 Max planes after a hole blew open on a jet during an Alaska Airlines flight in January.
content: Boeing on Wednesday reported a $355 million loss for the first three months of the year, as it deals with a quality crisis stemming from a Jan. 5 flight during which a panel blew off one of its planes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper
title: NATO Puts on a Show of Force in the Shadow of Russia’s War
description: The alliance’s largest exercises offer a preview of what the opening of a Great Power conflict could look like. How it ends is a different story.
content: About 90,000 NATO troops have been training in Europe this spring for the Great Power war that most hope will never come: a clash between Russia and the West with potentially catastrophic consequences.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir and Yan Zhuang
title: Australian Journalist Says She Was Pushed Out of India
description: Avani Dias said that she had been denied a visa renewal for weeks because of her reporting on the Sikh separatist movement. Indian officials disputed her account.
content: A senior journalist with Australia’s national broadcaster says she was effectively pushed out of India after her reporting on Sikh separatism angered the Indian government, accusing the authorities of hindering her from going to events, seeking to have her reporting taken down and refusing for weeks to renew her visa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy, Elizabeth Dias and Kellen Browning
title: Arizona House Votes to Repeal 1864 Abortion Law
description: The almost-complete ban on abortions in the state could go into effect as soon as June 8 if the State Legislature does not repeal it, the state’s attorney general said.
content: Arizona took a major step on Wednesday toward scrapping an 1864 law banning abortion, when three Republican lawmakers in the state House of Representatives broke ranks with their party and voted with Democrats to repeal the ban.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Schmidt
title: Rotting Fruit, an Animatronic Mouse and Other Highlights of the Venice Biennale
description: A tour of the international exhibition, which opened last week and runs through November.
content: The Venice Biennale, the art world’s most prestigious exhibition, opened last week to some fanfare, some criticism and a number of protests. Viewers generally look to the Biennale as a reflection of its time, and this one arrived at a fraught moment in history defined by political unrest and distrust for traditional systems of power. (And not for nothing, Indigenous and African artists, historically underrepresented in Venice, are notably more visible than in previous iterations of the show.) Here, a look at some of the standouts from the 2024 edition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Chaundler and Jason Horowitz
title: Spain’s Leader Says He’s Considering Resigning as Wife Faces Investigation
description: Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez put his public duties on hold. He said an inquiry into alleged influence peddling by his wife was politically motivated.
content: Spain’s prime minister, Pedro Sánchez, said late Wednesday that he was considering resigning after a judge opened an investigation into whether Mr. Sánchez’s wife had abused her position to help friends win public contracts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: The Humbling of Marjorie Taylor Greene
description: She has, in very little time, undermined the influence of her party’s entire right flank.
content: In our Trump-era politics, there’s always the question of how crazy is too crazy — how disruptive and extreme an elected official can get before becoming so embarrassing that members of her own team feel compelled to abandon her?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niki Kitsantonis
title: Athens Turns Orange Under a Saharan Dust Cloud
description: In Photos
content: The skies above Athens turned orange on Tuesday as clouds of dust from the Sahara blew north, casting an eerie glow over the Greek capital’s landmarks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana G. Smith
title: Could Eating Less Help You Live Longer?
description: Calorie restriction and intermittent fasting both increase longevity in animals, aging experts say. Here’s what that means for you.
content: If you put a lab mouse on a diet, cutting the animal’s caloric intake by 30 to 40 percent, it will live, on average, about 30 percent longer. The calorie restriction, as the intervention is technically called, can’t be so extreme that the animal is malnourished, but it should be aggressive enough to trigger some key biological changes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen
title: Meta’s A.I. Assistant Is Fun to Use, but It Can’t Be Trusted
description: Despite Mark Zuckerberg’s hope for the chatbot to be the smartest, it struggles with facts, numbers and web search.
content: In the last few days, you may have noticed something new inside Meta’s apps, including Instagram, Messenger and WhatsApp: an artificially intelligent chatbot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Alfonso Chardy, Who Helped Expose Iran-Contra Scandal, Dies at 72
description: A Miami Herald correspondent, he powered a team that won a Pulitzer Prize for investigative reporting and helped snare three other Pulitzers for the paper.
content: Alfonso Chardy, whose methodical reporting ushered The Miami Herald to a Pulitzer Prize for exposing the Iran-contra scandal in 1986 and contributed to three other Pulitzers that the newspaper won, died on April 9 in a Miami hospital. He was 72.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William Grimes
title: Helen Vendler, ‘Colossus’ of Poetry Criticism, Dies at 90
description: In the poetry marketplace, her praise had reputation-making power, while her disapproval could be withering.
content: Helen Vendler, one of the leading poetry critics in the United States, with a reputation-making power that derived from her fine-grained, impassioned readings, expressed in crystalline prose in The New Yorker and other publications, died on Tuesday at her home in Laguna Niguel, Calif.  She was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: April 24, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Weekday, Month Date, Year.
content: An article on Tuesday about a lack of evidence to support accusations tying many U.N. workers to Hamas described incorrectly what a review said about Israeli concerns about UNRWA employees. The review said that Israel had not flagged concerns about agency employees based on staff lists since 2011, not that Israel had not flagged any concerns about employees since 2011.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley and Tom Mashberg
title: Chicago Museum Says Investigators Have No Evidence Art Was Looted
description: In a court filing, the Art Institute of Chicago fought Manhattan prosecutors’ efforts to seize an important Egon Schiele drawing, denying that the Nazis had stolen it.
content: The Art Institute of Chicago has rebuffed an attempt by New York investigators to seize an Egon Schiele drawing in its collection, asserting in a strongly-worded 132-page court filing that the investigators have produced no evidence that the artwork was looted by the Nazis as they claim.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane L. Levere
title: A Mississippi Exhibition Takes on a Provocative Topic
description: A 183-canvas painting by Noah Saterstrom explores mental illness, his family’s struggle with it — and the state’s response to those impaired by it.
content: If museum exhibitions are meant to inspire and unsettle, the Mississippi Museum of Art has embraced its mission wholeheartedly, shining a light on a topic that is still largely taboo: mental illness and the state’s response to it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $700,000 Homes in Kentucky, New Hampshire and Minnesota
description: A 1926 brick house in Lexington, a two-bedroom condominium in Lyme and a Tudor Revival home in Minneapolis.
content: This house is in Ashland Park, less than a mile from the University of Kentucky and within a 15-minute walk of several university athletic fields. Woodland Park, which has an indoor aquatic center and a skate park, and a shopping center with a florist, an ice-cream parlor and a number of restaurants are also within walking distance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays
title: Mayor Adams Pushes Out Chairwoman of Police Oversight Board
description: Arva Rice was asked to resign after she criticized police handling of a fatal shooting investigation and requested more money and power to investigate misconduct.
content: The interim chairwoman of an independent police oversight panel who had fiercely criticized the Police Department will step down at the request of Mayor Eric Adams, according to three people familiar with the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wesley Parnell
title: Five Moments That Have Defined Donald Trump’s Trial So Far
description: Trials are wars of words. These are some of the most memorable that have been spoken as a jury hears the criminal case against Donald J. Trump.
content: The initial six days of Donald J. Trump’s criminal trial, the first for an American president, were a high-intensity spectacle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul, Alan Blinder and Liset Cruz
title: During a Chaotic Day, Columbia’s President Fights for Her Job
description: Nemat Shafik, the university’s leader, met privately with faculty members, who could soon decide to admonish her. Columbia’s board, though, made its support clear.
content: Nemat Shafik, Columbia University’s besieged president, faced skeptics on Wednesday in a meeting with the university senate that could vote to censure her over her handling of protests on the Upper Manhattan campus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: Can I Ask My Mother-in-Law Who My Wife’s Biological Father Is?
description: Although his wife has long maintained that she doesn’t want to know the identity of her birth father, a reader is tempted to find out on her behalf.
content: Ever since my wife was a girl, she was close to her stepfather, a lovely man who has now passed away. She always said he was her one and only father, and she had no interest in knowing who her biological father was. Recently, though, she hinted to me that she would like to know her biological father’s identity. But time is running out: We are in our 60s and her mother is approaching 90. Her mother is a forceful woman, and she has always been frank that it was her intention to become a single mother. She never mentioned the biological father’s name — not least because it was a badge of honor for my wife to proclaim that she had “only one dad.” I intend to ask my mother-in-law who the man was, but I worry about upsetting the family narrative. Thoughts?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman, David Montgomery, Jonathan Wolfe and Jenna Russell
title: Campus Protests Over Gaza Intensify Amid Pushback by Universities and Police
description: There were dozens of new arrests as universities moved to prevent pro-Palestinian encampments from taking hold as they have at Columbia University.
content: A wave of pro-Palestinian protests spread and intensified on Wednesday as students gathered on campuses around the country, in some cases facing off with the police, in a widening showdown over campus speech and the war in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Kim
title: Let This Breakfast Change Your Life
description: A simple miso-roasted salmon, part of a traditional Japanese spread, is both sustenance and self-care.
content: The chef Shota Nakajima goes to bed early and wakes up early. He walks his dog for an hour and a half every day. He doesn’t drink anymore, thriving on a diet of rice with grilled fish and pickles for most of his meals, especially breakfast. Getting to this place in life, a state of peace and equilibrium, was one of the hardest parts of transitioning from his 20s to his 30s, Nakajima says, but he is happier than he has ever been — as he describes it, “You know, just chilling, cranking.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Vehicle Crash That Injured Film Crew Was Caught on Video
description: The collision on the set of “The Pickup” is under investigation. Video shows an armored truck and an S.U.V. veering off a road before the truck flips onto the smaller vehicle.
content: A two-vehicle crash that injured several crew members on the set of the movie “The Pickup” is being investigated by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration, the federal agency said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari and David McCabe
title: Congress Passed a Bill That Could Ban TikTok. Now Comes the Hard Part.
description: President Biden has signed the bill to force a sale of the video app or ban it. Now the law faces court challenges, a shortage of qualified buyers and Beijing’s hostility.
content: A bill that would force a sale of TikTok by its Chinese owner, ByteDance — or ban it outright — was passed by the Senate on Tuesday and signed into law Wednesday by President Biden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Bread Spread
description: Step into the house of mirrors with Jeffrey Martinovic.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany
title: Binance Founder Should Get 3 Years in Prison, Prosecutors Say
description: Lawyers for Changpeng Zhao, the founder of the crypto exchange Binance, countered that he should receive no prison time.
content: Changpeng Zhao, the founder of the giant cryptocurrency exchange Binance, should go to prison for three years after breaking the law “on an unprecedented scale” and pleading guilty to a money-laundering violation, federal prosecutors wrote in a court filing on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Enduring Mayhem: Images From Year 3 of the War in Ukraine
description: A photographic chronicle of the third year of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
content: As the largest and deadliest war in Europe since the end of World War II stretches into its third year, the scale of the devastation wrought by Russia’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine continues to mount.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 318
description: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marina Harss
title: ‘So Far From Ukraine’: A Princely Dancer Finds a Home in Miami
description: Stanislav Olshanskyi has had to battle homesickness and adjust to Miami City Ballet’s style: quick, light, constantly in motion. He’s also the prince in “Swan Lake.”
content: “Imagine you’ve been rushing through the forest for hours,” the choreographer Alexei Ratmansky called out to Stanislav Olshanskyi as he ran across an airy ballet studio in Miami Beach. Olshanskyi, playing a prince, was searching for the woman he has been duped into betraying. “You are just now realizing the consequences of what you’ve done,” Ratmansky said. “How does it feel?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Hundreds at Harvard Protest Suspension of Pro-Palestinian Group
description: Students flooded Harvard Yard, the oldest part of the university’s campus, which officials recently closed to the public. The students set up tents for an “emergency rally.”
content: Hundreds of students gathered on Wednesday in Harvard Yard in Cambridge, Mass., to protest Israel’s war in Gaza and the Ivy League university’s suspension of a student group, the Harvard Undergraduate Palestine Solidarity Committee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Solar Companies Seek New U.S. Tariffs on Asian Imports
description: Firms warn that China uses its neighbors to skirt existing levies, depressing prices and threatening U.S. investments.
content: A group of seven leading solar manufacturers filed trade complaints on Wednesday formally requesting that the Biden administration impose tariffs on solar products being exported from Southeast Asia into the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush, Michael Forsythe and Walt Bogdanich
title: McKinsey Is Under Criminal Investigation for Its Opioid Work
description: Federal prosecutors are examining the consulting company’s role in helping “turbocharge” the sale of painkillers like OxyContin.
content: The Justice Department is investigating McKinsey & Company, the international consulting giant, for its role in helping drug companies maximize their sale of opioids.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth La Ferla
title: For Maxine Hong Kingston, Age Is Just Time Going By
description: At 83, the novelist and professor emerita at the University of California, Berkeley, likes to “go into the new.”
content: The Unstoppables is a series about people whose ambition is undimmed by time. Below, the writer Maxine Hong Kingston explains, in her own words, what continues to motivate her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Geoffrey Bunting
title: A Gun-Toting Crab Confronts a Fiendishly Tough Video Game Genre
description: With a rare suite of accessibility options for the Soulslike genre, Another Crab’s Treasure challenges the idea that difficulty is immutable.
content: Upon entering a cavernous room, its barely lit cobblestones reflecting a sickly green, you are charged by a towering beast that can be overcome only through a punishing sequence of precise dodges and parrying. The price for failure is severe. It is a lengthy journey to return to this spot, and one slip-up is all it takes to send you hurtling back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zeynep Tufekci
title: This May Be Our Last Chance to Halt Bird Flu in Humans and We Are Blowing It
description: “There’s a fine line between one person and 10 people with H5N1.”
content: The outbreak of H5N1 avian influenza among U.S. dairy cows, first reported on March 25, has now spread to at least 33 herds in eight states. On Wednesday, genetic evidence of the virus turned up in commercially available milk. Federal authorities say the milk supply is safe, but this latest development raises troubling questions about how widespread the outbreak really is.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Former Boeing Manager Says Workers Mishandled Parts to Meet Deadlines
description: Merle Meyers, who left Boeing last year after a 30-year career, said he was speaking publicly about his experience because he loved the company “fiercely.”
content: Two framed documents from a long career at Boeing hang side by side in Merle Meyers’s home: A certificate from 2022 that thanks him for three decades of service. And a letter he received months later reprimanding him for his performance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Libraries Hold Their Breath and Await the Budget
description: Five renovated branches are waiting to reopen, if the system receives sufficient funding.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. Today we’ll find out why five newly renovated branch libraries in New York City have yet to reopen. We’ll also hear what Mayor Eric Adams said in defending a nominee who worked for Rudolph Giuliani when he was mayor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Murray and Andrew Weissmann
title: The Supreme Court Has Already Botched the Trump Immunity Case
description: The court’s delay may have stripped citizens of the criminal justice system’s most effective mechanism for determining disputed facts: a trial.
content: The Supreme Court’s decision to hear oral arguments in Donald Trump’s immunity-appeal case on Thursday may appear to advance the rule of law. After all, few, if anyone, think that a majority of the court will conclude that a former president is completely immune from federal criminal liability.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Shulman
title: A Breakout Spanish Novel About Class and Trans Identity Comes to the U.S.
description: Alana S. Portero’s debut, “Bad Habit,” follows one woman’s coming-of-age in a blue-collar Madrid neighborhood.
content: Madrid Me Mata — or Madrid Murders Me, to replicate the alliterative Spanish — was the name of a short-lived but iconic magazine from the mid-1980s that chronicled the explosion of free expression in Spain’s capital during the post-Franco era. People danced, talked and partied to exhaustion while a deadly heroin epidemic emerged as the dark underside to the art, sex and music. The all-consuming intensity of life in the city seemed to have the power to kill its residents, figuratively and literally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Edward Moreno
title: Business Groups Sue to Stop F.T.C. From Banning Noncompete Clauses
description: The lawsuits contend the F.T.C. does not have the authority to prohibit companies from limiting their employees’ ability to work for rivals.
content: The U.S. Chamber of Commerce fulfilled its promise to sue the Federal Trade Commission over a ban on agreements that prevent workers from leaving a company for a rival, arguing in a lawsuit filed Wednesday that the agency overstepped its authority.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland, Benjamin Mueller and Emily Anthes
title: Dairy Cows Transported Between States Must Now Be Tested for Bird Flu
description: Since a new form of bird flu arrived in 2022, federal officials have sought to reassure Americans that the threat to the public remained low.
content: The Biden administration on Wednesday said that it would begin requiring dairy cows moving across state lines to be tested for bird flu, which has been spreading in herds for months. The new policy is part of a growing effort to stamp out the spread of a virus that federal health officials have sought to reassure Americans poses little risk to people so far.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Cristian Macelaru, Decorated Maestro, to Lead Cincinnati Symphony
description: He will begin a four-year term as the orchestra’s music director in the 2025-26 season, succeeding Louis Langrée.
content: The Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra, which has a history of attracting top conductors, including Fritz Reiner and Leopold Stokowski, announced on Wednesday that its next music director would be Cristian Macelaru, a Romanian-born maestro who has helped champion music education.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cara Buckley
title: RZA of Wu-Tang Clan Has Beef With Meat
description: The rapper, producer, actor and vegan talks about the connections between meat and masculinity, animal welfare and the environment.
content: RZA, the leader of the groundbreaking hip-hop collective Wu-Tang Clan, is a producer, rapper, writer, director, film scorer and actor. He is also a promoter of a meatless lifestyle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danny Hakim and Maggie Haberman
title: Arizona Charges Giuliani and Other Trump Allies in Election Interference Case
description: Those charged included Boris Epshteyn, a top legal strategist for Donald Trump, and fake electors who acted on Mr. Trump’s behalf in Arizona after the 2020 election.

content: Most legal experts say that former President Donald J. Trump will face deep skepticism at the Supreme Court on Thursday, when the justices will hear arguments on his claim that he is absolutely immune from prosecution on charges of plotting to subvert the 2020 election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: ‘Don’t Inject Bleach’: Biden Mocks Trump on Anniversary of Covid Comments
description: President Biden has homed in on the infamous moment, which crystallized the chaos of the Trump presidency, as he trolls his political opponent.
content: Four years ago this week, President Donald J. Trump suggested that Americans might want to inject disinfectant into their bodies to treat the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Review: John Adams’s ‘El Niño’ Arrives at the Met in Lush Glory
description: The opera-oratorio, an alternate Nativity story, featured a flurry of Met debuts, including the director Lileana Blain-Cruz and the conductor Marin Alsop.

title: Summer Lee, ‘Squad’ Member, Wins Democratic House Primary in Pennsylvania
description: A first-term representative, Ms. Lee defeated a centrist Democrat in a race that centered on her opposition to the war in Gaza.
content: Representative Summer Lee, a first-term progressive Democrat, won her primary contest in western Pennsylvania on Tuesday, according to The Associated Press, fending off a moderate challenger in a race that centered on her stance on the war in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley and Jeanna Smialek
title: High Borrowing Costs Have Some Democrats Urging Biden to Pressure the Fed
description: Polls show voters are angry about costs, like mortgages, and worried they will stay high if the president wins re-election.
content: Sky-high mortgage rates and other elevated borrowing costs are pinching American consumers ahead of the 2024 election, threatening President Biden’s chances at a second term.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Dangerous Game Is Underway in Asia
description: The new alliance structure Washington is pursuing in Asia won’t guarantee peace and stability — and may raise the risk of stumbling into a conflict.
content: This month, President Biden threw one of the most lavish state dinners in Washington’s recent memory. Celebrities and billionaires flocked to the White House to dine in honor of Prime Minister Fumio Kishida of Japan, posing for photos in front of an elaborate display of Japanese fans. Jeff Bezos dropped by; Paul Simon provided the entertainment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: TikTok’s Pro-China Tilt
description: A bill that will force the app’s Chinese owners to sell will soon become law.
content: The debate over TikTok has shifted very quickly. Just a few months ago, it seemed unlikely that the U.S. government would force ByteDance, the Chinese company that owns TikTok, to sell it. The platform is popular, and Congress rarely passes legislation aimed at a single company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Edward Moreno
title: Starbucks and Union Restart Contract Talks After Bitter Standoff
description: The company and Workers United, which represents more than 10,000 of the chain’s employees, broke off negotiation nearly a year ago.
content: Starbucks and the union that represents over 10,000 of its workers returned to the bargaining table on Wednesday for the first time in nearly a year, a pivotal moment in the yearslong battle between the coffee giant and its organized workers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pam Belluck
title: 5 Takeaways From the Supreme Court Arguments on Idaho’s Abortion Ban
description: The court’s ruling could extend to at least half a dozen other states that have similarly restrictive bans, and the implications of the case could stretch beyond abortion.
content: The abortion case before the Supreme Court on Wednesday featured vigorous questioning and comments, particularly by the three liberal justices. At issue is whether Idaho’s near-total ban on abortion is so strict that it violates a federal law requiring emergency care for any patient, including providing abortions for pregnant women in dire situations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: Signs Suggest That Invasion of Rafah Is All but Inevitable
description: Israel says an assault on Gaza’s southernmost city is vital to dismantling Hamas and has proposed evacuating civilians. But more than a million people have taken refuge in the city.
content: After weeks of delays, negotiations and distractions, Israel appeared to hint this week that its assault of Rafah — a city teeming with displaced persons above ground and riddled with Hamas tunnels below — was all but inevitable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Flooding Inundates Kenya, Killing at Least 32 and Displacing Thousands
description: The rain also killed farm animals and destroyed thousands of acres of crops.
content: Days of heavy rains have pummeled parts of Kenya, leaving at least 32 dead, 15 injured and more than 40,000 people displaced, according to officials. They said that flooding had killed nearly 1,000 farm animals and destroyed thousands of acres of crops, with more rain expected across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Carrie Robbins, Costume Designer for Dozens of Broadway Shows, Dies at 81
description: She made a classic wig and poodle skirt for “Grease” (using a bath mat and a toilet cover) and turned actors into Spanish inquisitors, British highwaymen and more.
content: Carrie Robbins, a meticulous and resourceful costume designer who worked on more than 30 Broadway shows from the 1960s to the 2000s, died on April 12 in Manhattan. She was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

content: Improv comedy became so influential in the first two decades of this century that you could make an argument it mattered more to popular culture than stand-up.

title: Authorities Offer $20,000 to Find Person Who Fatally Shot Dolphin
description: The dolphin, a juvenile found on a Louisiana beach, had injuries “consistent with being shot with a firearm,” marine officials said.
content: The authorities are offering a reward of up to $20,000 in exchange for information that can help them find the person who they believe fatally shot a juvenile dolphin at a beach in Louisiana, officials said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Biden Says Weapons Will Flow to Ukraine Within Hours as He Signs Aid Bill
description: The $95.3 billion measure comes after months of gridlock in Congress that put the centerpiece of President Biden’s foreign policy in jeopardy.
content: President Biden said on Wednesday that weapons would begin to flow to Ukraine “within hours” as he signed a $95.3 billion package of aid to Ukraine, Israel and Taiwan, reaffirming U.S. support for Kyiv after months of congressional gridlock put the centerpiece of the White House’s foreign policy in jeopardy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari, David McCabe and Cecilia Kang
title: ‘Thunder Run’: Behind Lawmakers’ Secretive Push to Pass the TikTok Bill
description: A tiny group of lawmakers huddled in private about a year ago, aiming to keep the discussions away from TikTok lobbyists while bulletproofing a bill that could ban the app.
content: Just over a year ago, lawmakers displayed a rare show of bipartisanship when they grilled Shou Chew, TikTok’s chief executive, about the video app’s ties to China. Their harsh questioning suggested that Washington was gearing up to force the company to sever ties with its Chinese owner — or even ban the app.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Trump’s Immunity Claim Joins His Plans to Increase Executive Power
description: The former president is asking the Supreme Court to put the presidency above criminal law as he pursues a broader agenda of expanding the office’s power should he win the election.
content: From the courts to the campaign trail, former President Donald J. Trump is challenging a hallmark of American-style democracy: its suspicion of concentrated power.

description: The Transportation Department issued new requirements on refunds when flights are canceled or delayed and on revealing “junk” fees before booking. Here’s what passengers can expect.

description: The argument, in a pretrial hearing, dealt with the unresolved question of whether a prisoner who completes such a sentence is entitled to release from military detention.
content: Regardless of the outcome of their someday trial, the men accused of plotting the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, can be held forever as prisoners in the war against terrorism in a form of preventive detention, a military prosecutor told the presiding judge on Wednesday.

title: A ‘Wonderland’ Adventure in the Bronx
description: A show at the New York Botanical Garden, inspired by Lewis Carroll’s books, will explore his fictional and real worlds through plants, art and artifacts.
content: Rabbits appear frequently at the New York Botanical Garden. The one that the public will soon see there, however, isn’t a typical little brown cottontail. About 12 feet tall, this creature will hold a pocket watch and have fur made of cream-colored Sedum foliage, a waistcoat of yellowy-green Sedum and a maroon jacket of Alternanthera leaves.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Wednesday Briefing
description: U.S. Senate approves long-stalled foreign aid.
content: The U.S. Senate voted overwhelmingly last night to approve a long-stalled $95.3 billion package of aid to Ukraine, Israel and Taiwan, sending it to President Biden for his signature and ending months of uncertainty about whether the U.S. would continue to back Kyiv against Russian aggression.

title: College Protesters Make Divestment From Israel a Rallying Cry

content: As they gathered near the guarded gates of Columbia University in Upper Manhattan on Tuesday, a hundred or so protesters began to chant: “Disclose, divest, we will not stop, we will not rest.”

author: By David Wallace-Wells
title: This Is What a Miracle Drug Looks Like. And It Only Costs $5 to Make.
description: The effects of semaglutide drugs won’t just be cosmetic
content: Last year was called the year of Ozempic, though it was also a year of Ozempic backlash and Ozempic shortages, which could persist for years. Even so, we appear very far from a peak for GLP-1 drugs, like Ozempic and Wegovy, which are powered by a molecule called semaglutide, and Mounjaro, which uses its cousin tirzepatide. It seems possible to imagine a future in which almost everyone is taking some variety of GLP-1 drug, and with a pretty good reason to do so.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jori Finkel
title: Art Seeks Enlightenment in Darkness
description: Many artists are dimming the lights of their museum shows, for a mix of symbolic and spiritual reasons.
content: To enter Kehinde Wiley’s show “An Archaeology of Silence” is to step into darkness, where only the art itself seems to emit light. The space feels somewhere between a crypt and a cathedral, featuring paintings and bronze sculptures of reclining Black bodies, spread out in repose or entombed like corpses, that appear to glow from within.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Donald M. Payne Jr., 65, New Jersey Representative in Sixth Term, Is Dead
description: A Newark Democrat, he succeeded his father, who was the first Black member of his state’s congressional delegation.
